results.title: Life sense: our lives through animal eyes. Part 2
results.creator_credit: BBC-TV, Lionheart TV International and John Downer
results.brief_description: How do we appear to the animals that share our lives? From the two million dustmites that inhabit our beds every night to the Macaque monkey picking 800 coconuts every day - animals are an integral part of human life. As well as providing companionship and food, they live on our bodies and influence the climate and the air that we breathe. But what do they see? What is the influence of our actions on their behaviour? This unique six-part BBC TV series provides the answers using stunning and innovative film and video techniques to truly show how our lives appear through animal eyes. Narrated by Andrew Sachs and contains the last three episodes - “Life and soul”, “Human life” and “Life in the balance”.

results.title: Life on the western marshes
results.brief_description: Each spring North America’s wild ducks and geese leave for their northern breeding ranges. Most of them land in the Canadian northwest, where, by June, the marshes shelter thousands of broods. Despite their rapid growth, only three out of every ten ducklings survive to learn to fly. Attacked by animal and bird predators, poisoned in scores by bacteria in low waters, threatened on the ground by magpies, ground squirrels, and gophers, and from the air by crows, yet the greatest danget to ducklings in man’s misuse of natural resources, for while times the watersheds flood the breading areas, at other times the level of water is allowed to sink dangerously low. ‘Ducks Unlimited’, an organisation formed by both sportsmen and farmers, helped by the on-the-spot community co-operation, is carrying out measures to preserve wildfowl from the various threats to their existence.

results.title: Life on the limit: cultivation and the environment
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Botanic man”.
Highlights the problems caused by the development of agriculture, focusing on India with the agricultural revolution in Assam which caused one of the first man-made ecological disasters. As the trees were felled to make way for cultivation, the soil was unprotected and the vital minerals were eroded from the soil by the heavy rainfall. It is an example of a paradox that has plagued almost every one of the developments modern man has achieved.

results.title: Life on the goldfields
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Peach’s gold”.
Bill Peach presents a look at life on the goldfields after the Eureka stockade. It was a colourful but often violent time, where fortunes were made and lost in a heartbeat. Using dramatised re-enactments as well as historical footage, the point is made that not all of those who came to the goldfields were fortunate enough to realise their dream, however they almost always embodied the pioneer spirit. Out of this free-wheeling era emerged the beginnings of a new society.

results.title: Life on other worlds
results.creator_credit: Coastal Community Colleges and David P. Stone
results.brief_description:
Episode number 26 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
Does life exist elsewhere in the universe? The search for life begins by looking for the chemicals of life - hydrogen and helium, which emanate from the stars. The atoms which make up our body, come directly from the stars, when supernovae exploded and dispersed their atoms into the molecular clouds around them. This chemical cocktail is the beginning of life. Astronomers are searching the heavens for this chemical cocktail and for signals from distant galaxies similar to our own. Ultimately this may show, that in all probability, we are not alone.

results.title: Life on ice
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Bruce Mackay, Adam Symansky, William Hansen and Peter Katadotis
results.brief_description: Sea-ice is the major habitat of some of the most spectacular wildlife in the world. This film focuses on the algal and animal life that survives in this harsh world. From the simple algae that thrives at the edge of the ice to the large narwhal and polar bear, Life on Ice looks closely at this unique chain of life. Fine photography shows rare views of sea birds, seals, whales and walrus diving beneath the canopy of ice.

results.title: Life on earth as I know it
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Lesley Furneaux-Cook and Penny McDonald
results.brief_description: A woman who is disillusioned with the world moves across town to move into shared accommodation with a house full of women. It is there that she meets Kate, someone who shares her despair, and on a night of torrential flooding they make some surprising discoveries about themselves. Cast includes Josephyne Oliveru, Gillian Clark and Genevieve Mooy.

results.title: Life on a string = Bian zou bian chang [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Serene Productions, Pandora Films, Beijing Film Studio, China Film Co-Production Corporation, Donald Ranvaud and Chen Kaige
results.brief_description: A blind musician has sustained himself with the belief that his blindness can be cured, but only after he has broken 1000 strings on his sanxian (a traditional three-stringed guitar). Although he has broken 995 he is now an old man approaching death who continues to roam the countryside with his restless young disciple promoting peace and harmony. This is not a conventional narrative, but a fable with an epic quality which explores the chasm between faith and magic, authority and disobedience, sacrifice and consummation. Kaige sees it as a plea for the rejuvenation of Chinese culture, civilization and identity, a plea which the Chinese authorities saw to be in some way subversive since they banned the film’s circulation in China. Cast includes Liu Zhongyuan, Huang Lei, Xu Qing. In Mandarin with English subtitles.
